attributes.title: Absolute and comparative judgments regarding capacity and motivation of the elderly
attributes.description: Participants will examine profiles of older/younger people and judge capacity and motivation of the targets.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The name of the project is the following: “Absolute and comparative judgments regarding capacity and motivation of the elderly”.

other.value: Because our younger target is 35 years old, we would like to avoid an ingroup identification by choosing a range of participants aged from 18 to 30. We also acknowledge that some participants are asked to compare the DV to 20 years old and include therefore participants age as a controlled variable in our analysis, because ingroup identification with the 20 years old could occur.

sample.value: Power analysis recommend a sample of 270. The final sample will be a total of 400 subjects, following the "at least 50 per condition" rule (Simmons, Nelson, & Simonsohn, 2013). We will stop data collection once 400 participants have submitted response on FouleFactory. (NB: Sometimes FouleFactory does not stop immediately data collection. This can result in a slightly bigger sample.)

analyses.value: We will run two separate regressions predicting (a) motivation for cognitive activities and (b) perceived capacity with target’s age (coded -0.5: young; 0.5 older), personal information (coded -0.5: with; 0.5 without) and type of judgment (coded -0.5: absolute; 0.5 comparative). This analysis will also control for age (scale), and the interactions between all the variables.

outliers.value:
For statistical analysis we will exclude participants scores who exceed Cooks’ (1997) cutoff point of 1, studentized residuals using the cutoff point of -3.87 and 3.87 and Mahalanobis distance of 19.98 (Stevens, 1984).
Methodological exclusion criteria concern participants who disagree on using their data and participants who failed an attention check, assuring participants read carefully instructions. We will also collect the time participants spend looking at our profile, the cutoff criteria will be fixed once we analyze times’ distribution.

dependent.value:
We will use the “Motivation for cognitive activities questionnaire” (Vallet, Schlemmer, Beaudoin, & Desrichard 2018) including the evaluation of perceived motivation and perceived capacity. Both refer to eight cognitive domains: problem solving, calculation, orientation, memorization, recall, planning and organizing, intellectual ability, tests and reading. Several examples are given for each domain, for example “shopping list” for memorization. 
Motivation and capacity are being measured on a scale from 1 to 7. A higher score in motivation and capacity indicates a better evaluation.
Motivation is divided into three subscales: extrinsic, intrinsic and identified motivation. The first one measures intrinsic motivation, “He likes it, he takes pleasure in it (satisfaction)”, the second extrinsic motivation, “He is forced to do so or he thinks that this is what is expected of him” and the third identified motivation “It is useful to him and/or it corresponds to him and/or he does it for his own good”. For each of the eight cognitive domains the three corresponding items will be summarized (24 items in total). We will add the eight scores to estimate the quantity of motivation attributed to the target. The lowest score therefore equaling 24 and the highest 168. 
The eight cognitive domains will be averaged to compute a global capacity score.

conditions.value:
We have eight conditions. IV one: target’s age: young vs. older (between), IV two: personal information: with vs. without (between), and IV three: type of judgment: absolute vs. comparative (between).
Participants will randomly be assigned to one of the eight experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Question: Are counter stereotypical information a way of striving against prejudice-based judgments on older targets’ and how does an absolute vs. comparative framework impact these judgment
Hypothesis: Age difference (lower perception of capacity and motivation of the older target) will appear only when the judgement is comparative (i.e. the target is compared to young people) and without personal information given about the targets (unless their age).

attributes.title: Lithuania Mortality analysis
attributes.description: This project aims to quantify the impact of alcohol control policy measures (i.e., increases in taxation, restrictions on availability, including minimum purchasing age regulation, drinking and driving legislation, and advertisement restrictions and bans) on all-cause mortality in Lithuania.

attributes.title: Same same, but different –A meta-analysis regarding the consequences of anthropomorphism in human-robot interaction
attributes.description: The meta-analysis aims to investigate how anthropomorphic design features affect the perception of robots, the attitudes towards the robot, the affects induced by the interaction and the behavior towards the robot. The heterogeneity of the results will be further analyzed by using the dimension of anthropomorphism, task relevancy, domain and exposure type as moderators.

q1.value: Same same, but different – A meta-analysis regarding the consequences of anthropomorphism in human-robot interaction

q3.value: Anthropomorphism, as a design element, is widely adapted in human-robot interaction to facilitate a more trustworthy and intuitive interaction. However, the results are inconclusive and hardly generalizable. Therefore this meta-analysis aims to investigate under which circumstances anthropomorphic design features lead to an improved human-robot interaction.

q4.value:
Research Questions
1.	What is the overall mean effect of anthropomorphism on the perception of the robot, the attitudes, the behavior and the affects towards the robot? 
2.	Does the type of anthropomorphism (appearance, movement, communication, and context) affect the effect sizes?
3.	Does the task relevancy affect the effect sizes? 
4.	Does the domain (like social or work-related) affect the effect sizes? 
5.	Does the exposure type (physical vs. hypothetical) affect the effect size?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This point is not applicable directly to our meta-analysis. However, the experimental studies from which we will be extracting data typically follow two or more group designs (one group exposed to a more anthropomorphic robot than the other).  Additionally studies without physical robot exposure often conduct multiple comparisons of robot pictures varying in their degree of anthropomorphism. Based on the diversity of the research field the examined studies will differ widely in the study designs.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
A comprehensive systematic review of literature, following the PRISMA statement (Moher et al., 2009) will be performed. Additionally the whole process will be illustrated via materials and templates for conducting meta-analysis in the age of open science (Moreau & Gamble, 2019). The literature search will be conducted by using library databases (including PsychINFO, PsycARTICLES, ACM Digital Library, IEEE Xplore Digital Library, ScienceDirect, SAGE Journals, Springer Link) and Google Scholar. The primary search terms were human-robot interaction and anthropomorphism (or humanlikeness or humanlike). 
The abstract and title screening will refer to the following inclusion criteria: 
Participants need to be human subjects (#1) which are at least 18 years old (#2) and physically and psychologically healthy (#3). The study design needs to include participants who either viewed or participated directly in interactions with robots through physical, virtual, or augmented means (#4), the comparison of at least two different degrees of anthropomorphism (#5) and each study had to include sufficient information to compute effect sizes (#6).

q13.value: The final size of the data set will depend on the results of the search and the extraction process.

q14.value: As described above, the sample size of the meta-analysis is mainly defined by the published data and the ability to obtain unpublished data sets.

q15.value: The search will be ended in April 2020 as soon as no more eligible studies will be found. Suggestions and data of experts will be accepted included till April, 30 2020.

question.value: No variables are measured directly. The variables of interest are diverse: perception of the robot , attitudes towards the robot, performance tendencies and actual performance. Wheter all variables are adequately covered will be decided by the data exclusion. This also applies for the moderator variables (e.g. type of anthropomorphism, task relevancy, domain , exposure).
The effect sizes will be calculated and combined as standardized mean differences.

The overall meta-analytic model will be conducted as random effects model to estimate the overall effect. Heterogeneity will be estimated by I2 and tested via Q Test for heterogeneity. Subsequently the moderator analyses will be run separately for the four moderators.

q20.value: The effect size is basically calculated from means and standard deviations. Additionally given effect sizes e.g. Cohen´s d or Pearson's r are transformed into the same effect size.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the meta-analytic model and the moderator model are significant.

q22.value: Outliers will be checked and if necessary removed after the estimation of the meta-analytic model and heterogeneity calculation using Cook´s distance.

q23.value: If a group mean or standards deviation, as well as an estimated effect size and n are not accessible, the effect will not be included.

registration_responses.q3: Anthropomorphism, as a design element, is widely adapted in human-robot interaction to facilitate a more trustworthy and intuitive interaction. However, the results are inconclusive and hardly generalizable. Therefore this meta-analysis aims to investigate under which circumstances anthropomorphic design features lead to an improved human-robot interaction.

attributes.title: Fracture strength of lithium disilicate based endocrowns versus resin based endocrowns: A systematic review
attributes.description: Endocrowns are post-endodontic monoblock crowns which extend into the pulp chamber of the teeth. Lithium disilicate based ceramics have been considered the best restorative material due to its high fracture strength and adhesive property. Recently, indirect resin based materials have been used as an alternative to ceramics to fabricate endocrowns due to its modulus of elasticity similar to dentin and high fracture strength.

q1.value: Beji Vijayakumar Joshna, Preethi varadan, Arathi Ganesh, Lakshmi Balaji, Mathan Rajan

q2.value: There is no difference in the fracture strength of lithium disilicate based endocrowns and resin based endocrowns.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A systematic review of in-vitro studies.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Inclusion criteria: Only in-vitro studies, studies where fracture resistance of endocrowns was assessed in extracted human permanent molars, studies where lithium disilicate based endocrowns were compared with indirect resin-based endocrowns.

Exclusion criteria: Case reports, literature reviews, letters to the editor, short commentaries, ex-vivo studies, dissertations, animal studies and studies reported in languages other than English.

A comprehensive literature search was performed using the following databases: Pubmed, Cochrane library, Google Scholar. 

Data extraction and risk of bias assessment of the included studies will be done.
Fracture resistance of lithium disilicate based endocrowns and resin-based endocrowns.
A meta-analysis will be performed if there is substantial homogeneity in the data. A fixed effect or random effect model analysis will be performed.

attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors in the elderly versus non-elderly patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus: a meta-analysis
attributes.description: Advanced age is risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), and old populations are increasing globally. Elderly patients with T2DM are at increased risk of cardiovascular complications, renal failure, retinopathy, and neuropathy. In addition, multiple comorbidities, polypharmacy and poor nutrition in older patients with T2DM may increase the risk of adverse events (AEs), such as hypoglycaemia, volume reduction, impaired renal function, resulting in special consideration in terms of the clinical management of them.Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) decreases plasma glucose as well as an osmotic diuresis and inducing urinary caloric loss. It is possible that osmotic diuresis contributed to lower blood pressure (BP), and caloric loss is involved in the mechanism of body weight loss. These benefits combined with its oral once a day recommend it may be a useful treatment in the management of older patients with T2DM. Although the advantage of SGLT2i in elderly patients, incidences of adverse events (AEs) of SGLT2i should not be ignored. Thus, this meta-analysis designed herein was undertaken to compare the influence of SGLT2i on eff and safety of elderly patients with the young ones.

q1.value: Yao Wang, Xian Shao, Shuai Huang, Saijun Zhou, Rui Zhang, Hongyan Liu, Pei Yu

q2.value: Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) is safe and effective for the elderly patients suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) relative to the young ones.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
METHODS
Criteria for included studies
Types of studies
We include randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and cohort studies. Studies were excluded for the following reasons: unavailable data, duplicate articles, testing of overlapping population, non-clinical publications, non-comparative studies.
Types of participants
We will include patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) recieving sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor (SGLT2i). No limitation was applied for the sub-types of SGLT2i, severity of the disease, or sex or race of the study participant subjects. And patients without T2DM, (2) patients not receiving SGLT2i, (3) present of any clinical sign of infection or inammation, (4) alcohol or drug abuse will be excluded.
Types of interventions
RCTs and cohort studies comparing the efficiency and safety of SGLT2i on elderly patients with young patients will be included. The intervention is the use of SGLT2i on old diabetes patients(≥65years), the comparison is the use of SGLT2i on young ones (<65 years).
Types of outcome measures
1.The primary outcomes
  The primary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of haemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), fasting blood glucose (FBG), body wight (BW), blood pressure (BP); the incidence of overall adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, AE leading to discontinuation.
2.The secondary outcomes　
The secondary outcomes will be the incedence of hypoglycemia, volume depletion (VD), genital infections (GIs), urinary tract infections (UTIs), renal function impairment, fracture and skin injury .
Search strategy
RCTs and cohort studies that comparing  comparing the efficiency and safety of SGLT2i on elderly patients with young patients will be included. We will identify relevant trials from systematic searches in the following electronic databases: PubMed, Medline, Web of Science, Embase, and Cochrane Library. We will also hand-search reference lists of trials identified in the initial searches and relevant review papers. The search deadline will be from inception to April 2020. There will be no restrictions on language, publication year, or publication type. The following keywords will be used: “SGLT2 inhibitor ”,“SGLT2”,“sodium-glucose co-transporter 2”,“individual names of SGLT2 inhibitor”, “old”,“elderly”, “T2DM”. In addition, all relevant authors will be contacted to supplement incomplete information.
Study selection and data extraction
Selection of trials
Titles and abstracts identified from the search strategies will be independently examined by two reviewers (YW and XS). If both reviewers judge that the trial does not meet eligibility criteria, we will exclude it. We will obtain the full-texts of all remaining articles and determine whether to include them by the same eligibility criteria. Any disagreements will be resolved by a third review author (SH). The reasons for exclusion of trials will be reported in the characteristics of excluded studies tables. 
Quality assessment
The methodological quality of the included studies will be independently assessed by two reviewers (Y.W. and SJZ). Two reviewers assessed the quality of included studies. Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale (NOS) was used to assess the quality of cohort studies; studies of low, intermediate and high quality were defined with NOS scores of 1-3, 4-6 and 7-9 in the meta-analysis, respectively.While, Revised Jadad rating scale was used to assess RCTs; studies of low and high quality were defined 1-3 and 4-5. Disagreements were resolved by argumentum. Publication bias was assessed by Begg's and Egger's tests. P < 0.05 was regarded as statistically significant. 
Data extraction
Two investigators (Y.W. and X.S.) independently extract the following information from each study: the author name, publication year and country, number of participants, mean age, participant baseline characteristics, SGLT2i types, the clinic outcomes including FBG, HbA1c, BP, BW, AEs and so on. If there are controversial ideas between the two investigators, a third investigator (P.Y.) will make the decision. Moreover, investigators can contact the corresponding authors included studies to obtain more information if important data were unavailable or absent. 
Statistical analysis
The meta-analysis will be carried out on the basis of the guidelines of the preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses (PRISMA) statement. All statistical analyses will be carried out with stata 14.0 (Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA). The standard mean difference (SMD) with 95% confifidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated on pooled effects for continuous variables, while odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated for dichotomous variables.The I2 statistic will be for assessing heterogeneity among the studies. It represents large, moderate and small heterogeneity when I2 statistic was higher than 75%, 50% and 25%, respectively. If I2＜50%, a fixed-effect model will be adopted; otherwise, a random effect model will be used. And we will use subgroup analyses and sensitivity analyses to find possible sources of the heterogeneity. Publication bias will be assessed by Begg's and Egger's tests. P< 0.05 will be regarded as statistically significant. 
Subgroup analysis
Where possible, the following subgroups analysis will be performed:(i)country (Asia vs non-Asia), (ii) the type of SGLT2i (e.g. canagliflozin，dapagliflozin，empagliflozin，ipragliflozin), (iii) the type of study (RCTs vs cohort studies). (iv) for enrollment sites (e.g. single centre vs. multi-centres).
Sensitivity analyses
The following sensitivity analyses will be performed: (i) by excluding studies with unpublished literature; (ii) by finding possible sources of the heterogeneity and (iii) by excluding studies with high bias based on ‘Risk of Bias’ assessment.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and cohort studies that comparing comparing the efficiency and safety of SGLT2i on elderly patients with young patients will be included. We will identify relevant trials from systematic searches in the following electronic databases: PubMed, Medline, Web of Science, Embase, and Cochrane Library. We will also hand-search reference lists of trials identified in the initial searches and relevant review papers. The search deadline will be from inception to April 2020. There will be no restrictions on language, publication year, or publication type. The following keywords will be used: “SGLT2 inhibitor ”,“SGLT2”,“sodium-glucose co-transporter 2”,“individual names of SGLT2 inhibitor”, “old”,“elderly”, “T2DM”. In addition, all relevant authors will be contacted to supplement incomplete information.
Inclusion criteria: Types of studies: We include RCTs and cohort studies. (2)Types of participants: we will include patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) recieving sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor (SGLT2i). No limitation was applied for the sub-types of SGLT2i, severity of the disease, or sex or race of the study participant subjects. (3)Types of interventions: RCTs and cohort studies comparing the efficiency and safety of SGLT2i on elderly patients with young patients will be included. The intervention is the use of SGLT2i on old diabetes patients(≥65years), the comparison is the use of SGLT2i on young ones (<65 years). (4)Types of outcome measures: the primary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of haemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), fasting blood glucose (FBG), body wight (BW), blood pressure (BP); the incidence of overall adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, AE leading to discontinuation. The secondary outcomes will be the incidence of hypoglycemia, volume depletion (VD), genital infections (GIs), urinary tract infections (UTIs), renal function impairment, fracture and skin injury.
Exclusion criteria: Studies were excluded for the following reasons: unavailable data, duplicate articles, testing of overlapping population, non-clinical publications, non-comparative studies. In additional, patients (i) without T2DM, (ii) patients not receiving SGLT2i, (iii) present of any clinical sign of infection or inammation, (iv) alcohol or drug abuse will be excluded.

q11.value: This study is designed as a meta-analysis, therefore, there is no need for estimating sample size.

question.value:
1.The primary outcomes
  The primary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of haemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), fasting blood glucose (FBG), body wight (BW), blood pressure (BP); the incidence of overall adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, AE leading to discontinuation.
2.The secondary outcomes　
The secondary outcomes will be the incedence of hypoglycemia, volume depletion (VD), genital infections (GIs), urinary tract infections (UTIs), renal function impairment, fracture and skin injury.

  The primary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of haemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), fasting blood glucose (FBG), body wight (BW), blood pressure (BP); the incidence of overall adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, AE leading to discontinuation.
2.The secondary outcomes　
The secondary outcomes will be the incedence of hypoglycemia, volume depletion (VD), genital infections (GIs), urinary tract infections (UTIs), renal function impairment, fracture and skin injury.

The meta-analysis will be carried out on the basis of the guidelines of the preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses (PRISMA) statement. All statistical analyses will be carried out with stata 14.0 (Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA). The standard mean difference (SMD) with 95% confifidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated on pooled effects for continuous variables, while odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated for dichotomous variables.The I2 statistic will be for assessing heterogeneity among the studies. It represents large, moderate and small heterogeneity when I2 statistic was higher than 75%, 50% and 25%, respectively. If I2＜50%, a fixed-effect model will be adopted; otherwise, a random effect model will be used. And we will use subgroup analyses and sensitivity analyses to find possible sources of the heterogeneity. Publication bias will be assessed by Begg's and Egger's tests. P< 0.05 will be regarded as statistically significant. Subgroup analysis: where possible, the following subgroups analysis will be performed:(i)country (Asia vs non-Asia), (ii) the type of SGLT2i (e.g. canagliflozin，dapagliflozin，empagliflozin，ipragliflozin), (iii) the type of study (RCTs vs cohort studies). (iv) for enrollment sites (e.g. single centre vs. multi-centres).Sensitivity analyses: The following sensitivity analyses will be performed: (i) by excluding studies with unpublished literature; (ii) by finding possible sources of the heterogeneity and (iii) by excluding studies with high bias based on ‘Risk of Bias’ assessment.

registration_responses.q1: Yao Wang, Xian Shao, Shuai Huang, Saijun Zhou, Rui Zhang, Hongyan Liu, Pei Yu
registration_responses.q2: Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) is safe and effective for the elderly patients suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) relative to the young ones.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q11: This study is designed as a meta-analysis, therefore, there is no need for estimating sample size.
registration_responses.q6.question:
METHODS
Criteria for included studies
Types of studies
We include randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and cohort studies. Studies were excluded for the following reasons: unavailable data, duplicate articles, testing of overlapping population, non-clinical publications, non-comparative studies.
Types of participants
We will include patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) recieving sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor (SGLT2i). No limitation was applied for the sub-types of SGLT2i, severity of the disease, or sex or race of the study participant subjects. And patients without T2DM, (2) patients not receiving SGLT2i, (3) present of any clinical sign of infection or inammation, (4) alcohol or drug abuse will be excluded.
Types of interventions
RCTs and cohort studies comparing the efficiency and safety of SGLT2i on elderly patients with young patients will be included. The intervention is the use of SGLT2i on old diabetes patients(≥65years), the comparison is the use of SGLT2i on young ones (<65 years).
Types of outcome measures
1.The primary outcomes
  The primary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of haemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), fasting blood glucose (FBG), body wight (BW), blood pressure (BP); the incidence of overall adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, AE leading to discontinuation.
2.The secondary outcomes　
The secondary outcomes will be the incedence of hypoglycemia, volume depletion (VD), genital infections (GIs), urinary tract infections (UTIs), renal function impairment, fracture and skin injury .
Search strategy
RCTs and cohort studies that comparing  comparing the efficiency and safety of SGLT2i on elderly patients with young patients will be included. We will identify relevant trials from systematic searches in the following electronic databases: PubMed, Medline, Web of Science, Embase, and Cochrane Library. We will also hand-search reference lists of trials identified in the initial searches and relevant review papers. The search deadline will be from inception to April 2020. There will be no restrictions on language, publication year, or publication type. The following keywords will be used: “SGLT2 inhibitor ”,“SGLT2”,“sodium-glucose co-transporter 2”,“individual names of SGLT2 inhibitor”, “old”,“elderly”, “T2DM”. In addition, all relevant authors will be contacted to supplement incomplete information.
Study selection and data extraction
Selection of trials
Titles and abstracts identified from the search strategies will be independently examined by two reviewers (YW and XS). If both reviewers judge that the trial does not meet eligibility criteria, we will exclude it. We will obtain the full-texts of all remaining articles and determine whether to include them by the same eligibility criteria. Any disagreements will be resolved by a third review author (SH). The reasons for exclusion of trials will be reported in the characteristics of excluded studies tables. 
Quality assessment
The methodological quality of the included studies will be independently assessed by two reviewers (Y.W. and SJZ). Two reviewers assessed the quality of included studies. Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale (NOS) was used to assess the quality of cohort studies; studies of low, intermediate and high quality were defined with NOS scores of 1-3, 4-6 and 7-9 in the meta-analysis, respectively.While, Revised Jadad rating scale was used to assess RCTs; studies of low and high quality were defined 1-3 and 4-5. Disagreements were resolved by argumentum. Publication bias was assessed by Begg's and Egger's tests. P < 0.05 was regarded as statistically significant. 
Data extraction
Two investigators (Y.W. and X.S.) independently extract the following information from each study: the author name, publication year and country, number of participants, mean age, participant baseline characteristics, SGLT2i types, the clinic outcomes including FBG, HbA1c, BP, BW, AEs and so on. If there are controversial ideas between the two investigators, a third investigator (P.Y.) will make the decision. Moreover, investigators can contact the corresponding authors included studies to obtain more information if important data were unavailable or absent. 
Statistical analysis
The meta-analysis will be carried out on the basis of the guidelines of the preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses (PRISMA) statement. All statistical analyses will be carried out with stata 14.0 (Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA). The standard mean difference (SMD) with 95% confifidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated on pooled effects for continuous variables, while odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated for dichotomous variables.The I2 statistic will be for assessing heterogeneity among the studies. It represents large, moderate and small heterogeneity when I2 statistic was higher than 75%, 50% and 25%, respectively. If I2＜50%, a fixed-effect model will be adopted; otherwise, a random effect model will be used. And we will use subgroup analyses and sensitivity analyses to find possible sources of the heterogeneity. Publication bias will be assessed by Begg's and Egger's tests. P< 0.05 will be regarded as statistically significant. 
Subgroup analysis
Where possible, the following subgroups analysis will be performed:(i)country (Asia vs non-Asia), (ii) the type of SGLT2i (e.g. canagliflozin，dapagliflozin，empagliflozin，ipragliflozin), (iii) the type of study (RCTs vs cohort studies). (iv) for enrollment sites (e.g. single centre vs. multi-centres).
Sensitivity analyses
The following sensitivity analyses will be performed: (i) by excluding studies with unpublished literature; (ii) by finding possible sources of the heterogeneity and (iii) by excluding studies with high bias based on ‘Risk of Bias’ assessment.
